title: And Then There Were None: Deeply Branched Edition
description: A significantly expanded interactive retelling with detailed acts, scene references, extended next-button sequences, and multiple sub-branches.

unfoldSteps.text: Your day begins normally until you discover a peculiar letter in your mailbox, sealed with dark red wax.
The letter invites you to Indian Island, claiming your specific skills are 'vital' and that all expenses will be covered.
The signature is cryptic: simply 'U.N. Owen.' You sense a puzzle hidden behind these formal words.

options.text: Next: Reflect on the invitation

unfoldSteps.text: You hold the letter, uncertain but intrigued. Why would you go?

options.text: A) 'Yes, I’ll gladly accept... (relaxing weekend job)'
B) 'I have reservations... (pay is good)'
C) 'I don’t trust this... (curiosity)'

unfoldSteps.text: A few days later, you find yourself aboard a small ferry cutting through misty waters.
Waves crash against jagged rocks as you near Indian Island’s weathered dock.
A figure—Mr. Rogers, the butler—greets you. He's polite but tense, and escorts you up a winding path toward a looming mansion.

options.text: Next: Enter the mansion foyer

unfoldSteps.text: In the foyer, eight others stand talking in hushed tones.
One by one, they introduce themselves: Vera Claythorne, Philip Lombard, William Blore, Dr. Armstrong, Emily Brent, General Macarthur, Tony Marston, and Judge Wargrave.
Each has been summoned by the mysterious Mr. Owen for varying reasons, none of which seem entirely clear.

options.text: Greet them politely
Keep your distance, observing quietly

unfoldSteps.text: Mr. Rogers guides everyone around the mansion: an elegant Foyer, a Drawing Room with ten peculiar figurines, a Dining Room fit for formal meals, and a well-stocked Library.
You also pass Guest Rooms, a Kitchen, and a locked Study rumored to belong to Mr. Owen. No one has seen the host yet.

options.text: Inspect the ten figurines in the Drawing Room
Ask Mr. Rogers about Mr. Owen’s absence
Proceed to your assigned Guest Room to unpack

unfoldSteps.text: Ten small soldier-like figurines rest on the mantel.
You recall a nursery rhyme about 'Ten Little Indians.' A chill passes over you as you consider the significance.

options.text: Discuss the figurines with Vera
Note them silently and rejoin the group

act1_node_askRogers.title: Asking About Mr. Owen
act1_node_askRogers.text: Mr. Rogers hesitates. 'Mr. Owen hasn’t arrived, sir/madam. We only have instructions to prepare for guests. He’s quite... private.' His discomfort is evident.

options.text: Press him for more info
Accept his explanation and move on

unfoldSteps.text: Your room offers a view of the stormy sea. A framed copy of 'Ten Little Indians' sits on the bedside table.
The rhyme’s lines are unsettling, but you can’t quite place why.

options.text: Read the rhyme thoroughly
Ignore it and head back out

unfoldSteps.text: That evening, you and the other guests gather in the Dining Room for dinner. The meal is lavish, if tense.
Suddenly, a gramophone crackles to life. A voice accuses each guest—including you—of a hidden crime.
Silence follows. Fear and outrage erupt as the recording ends.

options.text: A) Demand answers (confront everyone)
B) Deny wrongdoing (defend yourself)
C) Stay silent (observe reactions)

act1_node7.title: End of Act I
act1_node7.text: Tension soars. Doubt and fear flicker in each guest’s eyes. Tomorrow promises darker revelations. Act I ends here.

options.text: Proceed to Act II

unfoldSteps.text: Morning reveals a grim discovery: Tony Marston is dead at the table, apparently from poisoned whiskey.
Panic spreads. Vera is visibly shaken, while others suspect foul play.

options.text: Examine Tony’s glass for clues
Comfort Vera (she's distraught)

unfoldSteps.text: Each guest locks themselves in their room at night. A storm brews offshore, thunder rumbling in the distance.
You can’t sleep. The events replay in your mind. Why mention everyone’s secrets? Who is orchestrating this?

options.text: Check on Emily Brent (appears calm but possibly frightened)
Search the corridor for anything suspicious
Stay in your room to feel safe

unfoldSteps.text: You creep through the dimly lit hallway, footsteps echoing.
A door at the far end rattles slightly, as if someone is inside. Could it be Mr. Owen, or another guest?

options.text: Open the rattling door
Retreat to your room, unnerved

act2_node_lockedRoom.title: The Locked Room
act2_node_lockedRoom.text: You ease open the door and find... an empty storage closet. Old boxes and dusty furniture. A single faint footprint leads out, disappearing at the threshold.

options.text: Collect old letter (clue)

unfoldSteps.text: Daylight brings another tragedy—Mrs. Rogers found dead in her bed. 'She never woke up,' Mr. Rogers laments.
The supply boat fails to arrive, stranding everyone on the island.

options.text: Volunteer to search the island’s perimeter with Blore, Lombard, and Armstrong
Stay in the mansion to question other guests (Vera, Emily, Wargrave)
Investigate a faint noise from the basement (optional)

unfoldSteps.text: You descend uneven steps into a dank basement. Shadows dance on stone walls.
Among crates, you find old records and documents referencing 'ten figurines.' A cryptic note warns: 'Each must pay for their crime.'

options.text: Gather basement documents as clues
Rush upstairs, unsettled

unfoldSteps.text: You traverse rocky beaches. No sign of a hidden boat or Mr. Owen. Tensions run high.
Blore suspects Lombard is hiding something. Armstrong tries to mediate. You notice footprints that vanish at the tide line.

options.text: Confront Lombard about secrets
Suggest returning inside to regroup

unfoldSteps.text: You question Vera, Emily Brent, and Judge Wargrave. Paranoia laces every word.
Hidden diaries or letters suggest each guest might bear guilt. No direct evidence emerges—only suspicion.

options.text: Accuse someone openly
Offer calm reasoning, urging cooperation

unfoldSteps.text: Soon, a harrowing discovery: General Macarthur is found dead by the shore—struck on the head.
Three victims now. Everyone suspects each other. The figurines on the mantel are missing three pieces.

options.text: Accuse a search-party member
Search for footprints or clues at the scene

act2_node6.title: End of Act II
act2_node6.text: With three dead (Tony Marston, Mrs. Rogers, General Macarthur), paranoia is at a climax. No one trusts anyone. The storm outside builds, and the final act looms.

options.text: Proceed to Act III

unfoldSteps.text: Amid howling winds, the survivors gather in the Drawing Room. Each suspects the other.
Vera insists on locking all doors. Blore wants to interrogate everyone. Lombard stands by quietly, hand near his concealed revolver.

options.text: A) Accuse a specific character: 'I saw you sneaking around!'
B) Propose a group strategy: 'Lock up all weapons, move in pairs.'
C) Stay silent, watch for slip-ups

unfoldSteps.text: A shriek outside. Mr. Rogers is found dead near a woodshed, an axe lying beside him.
The rhyme’s pattern continues—another figurine gone. Tension reaches a boiling point.

options.text: A) Investigate immediately for any clues
B) Fetch Wargrave and Armstrong first
C) Retreat in shock, uncertain what to do

unfoldSteps.text: Alliances splinter further. Emily Brent prays, Wargrave suggests forming a tribunal, Lombard wants to search for the hidden killer, Armstrong is panicked.
The house’s power flickers. Shadows dance across the walls, fueling the sense of doom.

options.text: A) Insist no one separates—search together
B) Pair up with a trusted ally (Vera?)
C) Investigate alone, trusting no one

unfoldSteps.text: In the Library, you (or another guest) find damning documents: each victim’s 'crime' matches a line of the nursery rhyme.
The killer is punishing hidden sins. Is it one of you? Or is Mr. Owen truly present, hiding in the shadows?

options.text: A) Confront everyone with the proof
B) Confide secretly in Lombard or Vera
C) Keep it secret, hoping to avoid being targeted

unfoldSteps.text: With the figurines dwindling and the storm at its peak, the surviving guests gather in the Dining Hall or a high-cliff veranda—fear etched on every face.
You sense the endgame is near. Someone will strike soon, or you must unmask them first.

options.text: A) Accuse the prime suspect directly
B) Wait for a confession or slip-up
C) Attempt to escape down the cliff path in the raging storm

act3_node6a.title: Ending: Clear Victory
act3_node6a.text: You unmask the killer just in time. A tense confrontation ends with the murderer subdued. When rescuers finally come, the truth emerges, and a few survivors leave the island alive—but forever changed.

act3_node6b.title: Ending: Partial/Tragic
act3_node6b.text: Your hesitation allows more bloodshed before the final reveal. Only a handful survive the harrowing ordeal, their minds scarred by guilt and the haunting emptiness of Indian Island.

act3_node6c.title: Ending: Failed Escape
act3_node6c.text: Desperate, you flee into the raging storm, seeking any path off the island. Fate intervenes—whether by misstep or killer’s pursuit, you vanish. The island’s secrets remain sealed, and your fate unknown.

endings: Clear Victory: The killer is exposed, survivors rescued.
Partial/Tragic: Only a few survive to tell the tale.
Failure: You vanish or die trying to flee, leaving the mystery unsolved.

characters.name: Vera Claythorne
characters.background: Former governess. Possibly haunted by a past tragedy with a child.
characters.motives: Hired by Mr. Owen for secretarial tasks.

characters.name: William Blore
characters.background: Dubious police record, possibly framing innocents once.

characters.name: Dr. Armstrong
characters.background: High-profile doctor, rumored malpractice or negligence.
characters.motives: Asked to treat Mrs. Owen’s unknown ailment.

characters.name: Emily Brent
characters.background: Righteous, judgmental moralist. Possibly responsible for a past tragedy.
characters.motives: Invited by an 'old acquaintance' she barely recalls.

characters.name: General Macarthur
characters.background: Alleged war scandal or personal regrets.
characters.motives: Letter hinted at reuniting with old comrades.

characters.name: Tony Marston
characters.background: Reckless partying, rumored involvement in fatal accident.
characters.motives: Enticed by the promise of a grand holiday.

characters.name: Judge Wargrave
characters.background: Harsh rulings, rumored to have manipulated trials.

characters.name: Mr. Rogers
characters.background: Employed by Mr. Owen, uneasy about host’s absence.
characters.motives: Follows instructions meticulously, overshadowed by tension.

characters.name: Mrs. Rogers
characters.background: Works with Mr. Rogers, timid, easily frightened.
characters.motives: Distressed by rumors of Mr. Owen’s secrecy.
